repnme.cdata!: Sri Lanka - Second Agricultural Extension Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the outcome of the project was
            partially unsatisfactory, and sustainability for project
            activities in the long-haul is considered poor.
            Nevertheless, the Bank's performance in project design,
            appraisal and supervision was diligent. On the other hand,
            the government's performance was weak, due to premature
            methodology extension in the pilot area, overlaying the
            project with a broad rural development approach , and, a
            weak administration. The key lessons learned from this
            project show that: 1) currently, the public sector extension
            system results in a meager response to farmers' needs,
            thus, attempts should be made for the private sector and
            Non-governmental Organizations, to provide useful extension
            services; 2) the Government needs to ensure a consistent and
            long-term agricultural policy as a pre-requisite for
            extension projects to become successful; 3) a single
            extension methodology is hardly successful in a country with
            substantial diversity in farming systems, hence, various
            factors, such as climate, access to resources, education and
            commercial aspirations, require consideration for a
            successful extension program; and, 4) the community
            acceptance and feasibility of new extension methods, should
            be considered prior to implementation of such methods,
            particularly where technological change at the farm level is scarce.

18152512.theme: Pollution management and environmental health,Rural services and infrastructure,Rural policies and institutions
18152512.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Rural development

repnme.cdata!: Sri Lanka - Second Agricultural Extension Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project objectives are to increase
            farmers' income and agricultural production by
            improving farm productivity through, inter alia, promotion
            of innovative technology.  To achieve this objective, the
            project will:  (a) strengthen agricultural extension
            services (except for tree crops); and (b) develop a national
            seed policy.  The nationwide project will consists of:  (a)
            a multifaceted program to improve agricultural extension
            services, including closer integration of existing extension
            services, improved use of mass media, strengthened plant
            protection, quarantine and pest control, safer and more
            effective use of pesticides, training, and a private sector
            pilot extension program; (b) improved seed policy; and (c)
            establishment of a project management unit.
